Identifying Characteristics: Tadpoles are olive green and iridescent creamy-white below
Adults are green, greenish-brown, brownish, yellowish-green, and olive, with some rare individuals being blue
Often brighter color in front with small, random black spots
Legs have dark bands across them and their skin is yellowish or white below the bands
Dorsolateral ridges, prominent, seam-like skin folds that run down the sides of the back Very fast and long leaps Size: typically 5-10cm as adults
Biology: Sexually dimorphicâ€”mature females are typically larger than males, the male tympanum is twice the diameter of the eye, whereas in females, the tympanum diameter is about the same as that of the eye, males have bright yellow throats
Breeding season lasts from April to August
Male mating call sounds like a banjo string being plucked
Female lays eggs (between 1000-7000) attached to submerged vegetation
Metamorphosis can occur within the same breeding season (in 3-5 days) or tadpoles may overwinter to metamorphose the next summer
Males become sexually mature at one year, females may mature in either two or three years
Diet: Adults eat any mouth-sized animal they can capture - insects, spiders, fish, crayfish, shrimp, other frogs, tadpoles, small snakes, birds, and snails
Tadpoles graze on algae and water plants
Range: Nearctic region - United States and Canada (from Maine and eastern Canada through the Great Lakes region to western Ontario and Oklahoma, south to eastern Texas, east into northern Florida and extending up the entire east coast of the United States)
